There is also evidence that knowledge about pensions and Social Security affects retirement decisions; see Chan and Huff Stevens (2003); Duflo and Saez (2003, 2004); and Mastrobuoni (2005). It is possible that causality may also go the other way: that is, those who plan may also become more financially literate and develop the ability to do retirement calculations; for discussion of endogeneity considerations, see Lusardi and Mitchell (2007a). The analysis herein uses the 2004 wealth data that included imputes for those who did not report assets or debt.
